Option B. Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which increases the release of GnRH, and subsequently increases LH and FSH secretion from the pituitary gland.

 

Option C. Causes endometrial thinning: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate has an anti-estrogenic effect on the endometrium, which can lead to thinning of the endometrial lining, potentially impacting embryo implantation.

 

Option D. Can be used with gonadotropins: This statement is correct. Clomiphene can be used in combination with gonadotropins for ovulation induction, but this approach increases the risk of multiple pregnancies due to the stimulation of multiple follicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clomiphene citrate induces ovulation by inhibiting the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased secretion of gonadotropins and the development of multiple follicles. It can cause endometrial thinning and can be used with gonadotropins, but it does not cause monofollicular development.

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Na, K

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

During the early portion of the action potential, the ratio of sodium to potassium conductance increases more than 1000-fold. Therefore, far more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than do potassium ions to the exterior. This causes the membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.

 

Then the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels to open, so that the ratio of conductance shifts far in favor of high potassium conductance but low sodium conductance. This allows very rapid loss of potassium ions to the exterior but virtually zero flow of sodium ions to the interior.

Consequently, the action potential quickly returns to its baseline level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, sodium conductance increases first (Channel A), followed by an increase in potassium conductance (Channel B), causing depolarization and subsequent repolarization of the neuron.

questions.text: A young patient undergoing treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) presents with symptoms of weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine). Which of the following drugs is likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethionamide.

 

Ethionamide, a second-line antitubercular agent used in the treatment of MDR-TB, is known to cause hypothyroidism as a side effect. This condition is characterized by an underactive thyroid gland, leading to symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. The laboratory findings of elevated TSH and low levels of T3 and T4 further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cycloserine: Cycloserine is used in the treatment of MDR-TB, but its side effects are more commonly neurological, including mood changes and seizures. It is not typically associated with thyroid dysfunction.

 

Option C. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is used in TB treatment and is known for its potential ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, rather than effects on thyroid function.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is a first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects include hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia but not typically hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide, a second-line drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), can cause hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, lethargy, elevated TSH, and low T3 and T4 levels.

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Botulinum

 

The image given above depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

 

Clostridium botulinum is non-invasive. Its pathogenesis is due to the production of powerful neurotoxin ‘botulinum toxin’ (BoNT). It produces flaccid paralysis. There are 7 serological types of botulinum neurotoxin labeled as types A, B, C [C1 C2], D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is caused mainly by types A, B, E and F (rarely).

 

After entry (either ingested, inhaled, or produced in a wound), botulinum toxin is transported via the blood to peripheral cholinergic nerve terminals. The most common nerve terminal sites are neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia. It does not affect the CNS.

 

Botulinum toxin causes proteolysis of snare proteins that are required for the excocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles, thereby preventing the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the peripheral nerve endings, including neuromuscular junctions (presynaptic inhibition). This results in a lack of stimulus to the muscle fibers, irreversible relaxation of the muscles to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal, and flaccid paralysis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tetanus: Tetanus toxin (produced by Clostridium tetani) acts by inhibiting neurotransmitter release in the central nervous system by cleaving synaptobrevin, another SNARE protein, but it causes spastic paralysis rather than flaccid paralysis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Diphtheria toxin (produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae) inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), which is a completely different mechanism from that of botulinum toxin.

 

Option D. Pertussis: Pertussis toxin (produced by Bordetella pertussis) modifies the signaling of G-protein coupled receptors by ADP-ribosylating the Gi protein, thereby affecting cellular communication but not directly impacting acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by preventing the release of acetylcholine at peripheral nerve endings through the proteolysis of SNARE proteins necessary for acetylcholine vesicle exocytosis.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers

questions.text: Urinary alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin
 

Urinary alkalinization is a key treatment in aspirin toxicity. Aspirin (salicylate) is a weak acid, and alkalinizing the urine increases the ionization of salicylates. This ionization traps salicylates in the urine, preventing their reabsorption and enhancing their elimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: Urinary alkalinization is not a standard treatment for beta blocker toxicity. Management of beta blocker overdose typically involves supportive care and, in severe cases, specific antidotes like glucagon or high-dose insulin.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Similar to beta blockers, urinary alkalinization is not a primary treatment for calcium channel blocker overdose. Treatment often includes calcium infusions, glucagon, and other supportive measures.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: For acetaminophen toxicity, the antidote N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is used. Urinary alkalinization is not effective for acetaminophen overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary alkalinization is most useful in the treatment of aspirin (salicylate) toxicity because it increases the elimination of salicylates by trapping them in the urine through ionization. This method is not effective for beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, or acetaminophen toxicity.

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1:1000 I.M. - 0.5 ml

 

Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of ischemic heart disease. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-HT agonist

 

Chest pain in an elderly woman with a history of ischemic heart disease, who is on treatment for migraine, could potentially be linked to the mechanism of action of her migraine medication. Among the options given 5-HT agonists can cause this adverse effect. Triptans and ergotamine are a group of drugs that are used in acute attacks of migraine. They act on 5HT1B/1D receptors as agonist and cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. Therefore, they should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease as they can precipitate myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-HT Antagonist: Serotonin (5-HT) antagonists like cyproheptadine and methysergide etc are used for prophylaxis of migraine (not in treatment). These drugs are not commonly associated with causing chest pain or exacerbating ischemic heart disease.

 

Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker Action: While calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are used in migraine prophylaxis, they are generally heart-protective and used in the treatment of angina and hypertension due to their vasodilatory effects. It's unlikely that CCBs would cause chest pain.

 

Option D. Nitric Oxide Mediated Vasodilation: Nitric oxide donors (like nitrates) are used in the treatment of angina due to their vasodilatory effects. They are not typically used in migraine treatment, and their vasodilatory action would be more likely to relieve, rather than cause, ischemic chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-HT Agonist includes medications like triptans (e.g., sumatriptan), which are commonly used in migraine treatment. Triptans are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists and can cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels. In patients with ischemic heart disease, this vasoconstriction can exacerbate angina (chest pain) or precipitate myocardial infarction, especially if the coronary arteries are already compromised.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has a lesion over the face as shown below. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BCC (Basal cell carcinoma)

 

The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, especially in older individuals with sun exposure. It often appears as a pearly or waxy bump with central depression, which can bleed easily. Itching is also a common symptom associated with BCC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatofibrosarcoma: Dermatofibrosarcoma is a rare, slow-growing soft tissue tumor that typically presents as a painless, raised, flesh-colored or brownish lesion. It does not commonly cause bleeding or itching.

 

 

Option B. Marjolin's Ulcer: Marjolin's ulcer refers to a malignant transformation of a chronic non-healing wound, scar, or ulcer. It is often associated with long-standing inflammation or trauma. While it can present with bleeding, it typically doesn't cause itching as a primary symptom.

 

 

Option D. Naevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign skin lesion. While moles can occasionally be itchy, they do not usually cause bleeding unless they are irritated or traumatized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is an epithelial tumor that arises from basal cells layer of epidermis. It is the most common type of skin cancer. Most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Clinically it can present either as nodular or pigmented BCC. Features of nodular BCC are:

 

  1. Small, slowly growing pearly nodule
  2. Tortuous telangiectatic vessels on the surface
  3. Rolled borders
  4. Central crusting

 

The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index


Therapeutic Drug Monitoring has to be done for drugs that have a narrow safety margin. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that acts by inhibiting the protein synthesis at the 30S ribosomal subunit of the bacteria. It is nephrotoxic as well as ototoxic. It has a narrow therapeutic margin; therefore, it requires TDM.

 

Option B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, and these drugs are known for their narrow therapeutic index. TDM is important for gentamicin to ensure effective therapeutic levels are achieved without causing toxicity. Aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity (kidney damage) and ototoxicity (hearing loss), so monitoring blood levels is crucial to avoid these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index: This is not typically the case. Penicillin, for the most part, does not have a narrow therapeutic index, and Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is generally not required for penicillin.

 

Options C. TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects: While it's true that both drugs can have side effects, TDM is generally only recommended for gentamicin because of its narrow therapeutic window and potential for serious side effects. Penicillin does not typically require TDM.

 

Options D. Both drugs do not need monitoring: This statement is incorrect because gentamicin does require monitoring due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Primaquine

 

Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It inhibits transmission of malaria. Artemisinin also have high gametocidal activity against all the species.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Primaquine interferes with the mitochondrial electron transport chain in the parasite, leading to the death of gametocytes and hypnozoites (dormant liver forms in Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale).
  • By eliminating gametocytes, primaquine helps reduce the spread of malaria within a community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: is primarily effective against the erythrocytic forms of Plasmodium species but does not have gametocidal activity against all species. It is not effective against the dormant liver forms or the gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Option C. Quinine: is effective against the asexual blood stages of Plasmodium species but lacks significant activity against the gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum. It does not have a broad gametocidal effect against all species.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primaquine is the antimalarial drug that is gametocidal to all Plasmodium species, making it essential for preventing the transmission of malaria and addressing relapses in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale infections.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting that started 12 hours ago. She has a history of chronic constipation for which she has been using an over-the-counter laxative regularly for the past year. On examination, her abdomen is distended with tenderness on palpation but no signs of guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory tests show mild hypokalemia and normal white blood cell count. An abdominal CT scan shows evidence of a thickened colonic wall but no signs of perforation or obstruction. The patient is admitted for further evaluation. During colonoscopy, the mucosa appears darkly pigmented with a brownish-black hue. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Senna

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical findings and colonoscopy appearance described in this case are indicative of melanosis coli, a condition characterized by the pigmentation of the colonic mucosa due to chronic use of stimulant laxatives, such as Senna. Melanosis coli is typically benign and results from the accumulation of apoptotic macrophages in the colonic lamina propria. The pigmentation is usually brownish-black and appears most prominently in the proximal colon. This condition is often associated with long-term use of stimulant laxatives, such as Senna, cascara sagrada, and bisacodyl. Senna is known to stimulate bowel movements by irritating the colonic mucosa, leading to faster transit and decreased water absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyethylene glycol: This is an osmotic laxative that works by retaining water in the stool to soften it and promote bowel movements. It does not have the pigmentary effects associated with stimulant laxatives and is not linked to melanosis coli.

 

Option B. Magnesium citrate: This is another osmotic laxative that draws water into the intestines, leading to bowel distention and stimulation of peristalsis. It does not cause the pigmentation changes seen in melanosis coli and is not associated with chronic mucosal damage.

 

Option D. Lactulose: Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide used to treat constipation and hepatic encephalopathy. It acts as an osmotic laxative but does not cause melanosis coli, as it does not stimulate the bowel mucosa in the same manner as stimulant laxatives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanosis coli is a benign condition characterized by dark pigmentation of the colonic mucosa due to chronic use of stimulant laxatives like Senna. These laxatives should not be used for extended periods due to potential mucosal damage and risk of atonic colon.

choices.text: Ciprofloxacin and tinidazole
Only ciprofloxacin
Only ORS
Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole and ORS

questions.text: A young male developed 5 episodes of loose stools 2 hours after eating in a restaurant. He is afebrile and has mild dehydration. What should be the treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only ORS

 

Management of diarrhea in an afebrile patient is mainly based on the presence or absence of dehydration. In case of no dehydration or some dehydration, we can manage it using only ORS. If there is severe dehydration, then IV fluids have to be used. There is no role of antibiotics in such case. Empirical antibiotics are used only in case of febrile patients. If only bacterial etiology is suspected, the Ciprofloxacin is used, and it amoebiasis or giardiasis is suspected, then Metronidazole is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin and tinidazole: This combination is used for treating bacterial and protozoal infections. However, it is not indicated here because the patient is afebrile and the condition is likely self-limiting.

 

Option B. Only ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic used for bacterial infections. Since the patient is afebrile and has mild dehydration, there is no indication for antibiotic therapy. ORS alone is sufficient.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole and ORS: This combination is unnecessary and potentially harmful. Overuse of antibiotics can lead to resistance and other side effects. The primary treatment needed is rehydration with ORS

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young male with afebrile, mild dehydration due to acute diarrhea, the appropriate treatment is oral rehydration solution (ORS) to replace lost fluids and electrolytes. Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a suspicion of bacterial infection with severe symptoms or fever.

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient who is on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

 

The given clinical scenario of white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient using inhalational steroids points to diagnosis of oral candidiasis and drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.

 

Asthma patients use MDI which can result in deposition of steroids in the oropharyngeal space, which might lead to cough, dysphonia, and oral candidiasis.

 

Clotrimazole is classified under Azole group of Anti-Fungal drugs, acts by inhibiting fungal sterol (ergosterol) synthesis. Used topically in treatment for topical fungal infections like tinea and candida

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is mainly used against dermatophytes and is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. But it is not effective against Candida.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Terbinafine acts by inhibiting the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase. which reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. Used to treat nail onychomycosis and other dermatophytosis.

 

Option D. Flucytosine: Flucytosine acts by inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis. Used exclusively to combat systemic fungal infections (e.g., cryptococcal meningitis) in combination with amphotericin B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clotrimazole is the drug of choice for treating oral candidiasis, especially in patients who develop the condition as a side effect of inhalational steroid use. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis, compromising the fungal cell membrane integrity.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Schedule H drugs

 

Under the "Drugs and Cosmetics Act," certain schedules classify drugs based on various criteria, including the need for prescription, potential for abuse, and manufacturing practices.

 

  • Schedule H drugs: These drugs can only be sold with a prescription from a registered medical practitioner. They are labeled with "Rx" written in black color to indicate that they should be dispensed only on prescription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schedule M drugs: These pertain to Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) for pharmaceuticals and do not indicate a requirement for prescription-based sale.

 

Option C. Schedule J drugs: This schedule lists diseases and ailments for which a drug may not claim to prevent or cure. It does not pertain to prescription requirements.

 

Option D. Schedule X drugs: These are psychotropic substances with a high potential for abuse and must be sold with a valid prescription. While Schedule X drugs also require a prescription, the question specifically asks about drugs that should be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner, making Schedule H drugs the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The important schedules under the “Drugs and Cosmetics Act” are:

 

  • Schedule H – The drugs that can be sold only by prescription where Rx is written in black color.
  • Schedule H1 – for antibiotics where Rx is written in red color.
  • Schedule G – Drugs that need labelling as “Dangerous to use except under medical supervision.”
  • Schedule X – Psychotropic drugs that have a high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid prescription only.
  • Schedule P drug – describes the life period of drugs in months (unless otherwise specified) between the date of manufacture and date of expiry.
  • Schedule M – GMP or Good Manufacturing Practices.
  • Schedule J - List of diseases and ailments which a drug may not claim to prevent or cure

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause a pleural pathology? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used primarily in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and increasing insulin sensitivity. Metformin is not associated with pleural pathologies, making it the correct choice in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methysergide: Methysergide is a medication used to prevent migraine headaches and is known for its potential to cause retroperitoneal and pleural fibrosis. This pleural pathology is a serious adverse effect, although the drug is not commonly used today due to this risk.

 

Option C. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of various cancers. One of its well-known side effects is pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as pulmonary fibrosis. Pleural involvement, including pleural effusions and fibrosis, can occur secondary to its pulmonary effects.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic used primarily for urinary tract infections. It can cause pulmonary reactions, including acute, subacute, and chronic pulmonary reactions. These reactions can involve the pleura, leading to pleural effusions and other pleural pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is not associated with causing pleural pathologies, unlike Methysergide, Bleomycin, and Nitrofurantoin, which have known risks of causing pleural and pulmonary complications.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her tumor is found to be HER2-positive but estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. The tumor was resistant to trastuzumab. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient's breast cancer?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lapatinib

 

Lapatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of HER2-positive but trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that is commonly used for the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer, but some patients may develop resistance to this drug over time. Lapatinib works by targeting the HER2 receptor, which is overexpressed in HER2-positive breast cancer, and can be effective in treating breast cancer that has become resistant to trastuzumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sorafenib is a kinase inhibitor that is primarily used for the treatment of advanced liver cancer and kidney cancer. It works by blocking the activity of several proteins that promote the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Option C. Vismodegib is a hedgehog pathway inhibitor that is used for the treatment of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer. It works by blocking the hedgehog signalling pathway, which is involved in the development and growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D. Erlotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that is used for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, and other types of cancer. It works by blocking the activity of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lapatinib is an effective treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer, especially in cases where the cancer has become resistant to trastuzumab. It works by targeting the HER2 receptor and can help manage this specific type of breast cancer.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amoxicillin

 

Out of the options given above, amoxicillin is the only drug which is an antibiotic. It is an amino penicillin. Allergic reactions in the form of skin rashes to Penicillin group of antibiotics are very common, out of which it is the highest with aminopenicillins.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used in the treatment of asthma to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids like prednisolone are not typically associated with causing maculopapular rashes. In fact, they are often used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

 

Options B. Salbutamol: Also known as albuterol, this is a bronchodilator used to relieve bronchospasm in conditions like asthma. Salbutamol is not commonly associated with skin rashes like a maculopapular rash.

 

Options C. Fexofenadine: This is an antihistamine used for allergic reactions. It is unlikely to cause a maculopapular rash and is more commonly used to treat such rashes when they are due to allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoxicillin, an aminopenicillin antibiotic, is commonly associated with allergic reactions, including maculopapular rashes. This is a well-known side effect of penicillin antibiotics. Prednisolone, salbutamol, and fexofenadine are less likely to cause such reactions, and in the case of prednisolone and fexofenadine, they are actually used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in OPD with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid tumor

 

  • The given clinical scenario and image points to a diagnosis of parotid tumor.
  • MC benign parotid tumor is Pleomorphic Adenoma.
  • MC site: superficial lobe of parotid

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst: Seen in children at lines of mesodermal fusion like outer canthus of eye.

 

 

Option C. Sebaceous cyst: Will show soft consistency and punctum.

 

 

Option D. Swollen cervical lymph node – will show firm consistency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A parotid tumor, particularly pleomorphic adenoma, is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.
  • It is characterized by slow growth, a variable consistency, and mobility, commonly found in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland.
  • Proper diagnosis involves imaging and FNAC, with treatment typically involving surgical removal while preserving the facial nerve if possible.

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after an RTA. He has suffered chest trauma, has respiratory rate of 44/min and BP is 90/40 mm of hg. He is conscious and speaks single words. There is a hyper-resonance on percussion on the involved side of his chest. What will be your immediate next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercoastal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with varicose veins comes to OPD with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C4a

 

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C2:

 

  • Description: Varicose veins without any additional skin changes or complications.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which indicates a more advanced stage than C2.

 

Option B. C3:

 

  • Description: Presence of oedema without skin changes.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, not just oedema.

 

Option D. C4b:

 

  • Description: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which is classified under C4a, not the more severe skin changes seen in C4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, the presence of eczema or pigmentation in a patient with varicose veins is classified as stage C4a.

questions.text: A bank employee, felt depressed with no interest in activities, came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea, or excessive saliva production, is not a common side effect of SSRIs like escitalopram. It is more commonly associated with the atypical antipsychotic drug clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia, or difficulty achieving orgasm, is a well-known side effect of SSRIs due to their impact on serotonin levels, which can interfere with sexual function.

 

Option C. Nausea: Nausea is one of the most common side effects of SSRIs. It typically occurs at the beginning of treatment and may subside with continued use.

 

Option D. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams are another common side effect of SSRIs. They occur due to the influence of increased serotonin levels on sleep patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Escitalopram is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).
  • Other SSRIs include Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Fluvoxamine etc.
  • Side-effects of SSRI include:
  • Most common: Nausea, Vomiting
  • Next most common: Anxiety etc.
  • Other side effects- Delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, diarrhea, vivid dreams etc.
  • Main drug which causes sialorrhea is CLOZAPINE (an atypical anti-psychotic drug)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/488
